description: This is an intermediate-level course in macroeconomics and the global economy, including topics in monetary and international economics. The goal is to provide a unified framework for understanding macroeconomic events and policy, which govern the global economic environment of business. The course analyzes the determinants and behavior of employment, production, demand and profits; inflation, interest rates, asset prices, and wages; exchange rates and international flows of goods and assets; including the interaction of the real economy with monetary policy and the financial system. The analysis is applied to current events, both in the US and abroad.
name: MONETARY ECON & GLOB ECO

values.comments:
Monetary Economics and the Global Economy is an intermediate-level study of macroeconomics. The goal of this class is to provide a framework for analyzing macroeconomic events and macroeconomic policy. Topics discussed during the semester are broken up into two main categories. The first category focuses on the analysis of efficiently operating labor markets, goods markets, and asset markets. The second category focuses on short-run business cycle analysis.

The majority of students found this course to be difficult. Many students mentioned that the lecture slides often had errors that were corrected in class. Most also reported that they found the best resource for the class to be the textbook. Some students mentioned that the course had a lot of overlap with ECON 10, which made some of the material repetitive. 

Students said that Professor Drozd was very knowledgeable, but that he had some difficulty transferring his knowledge into teaching. A select number of students mentioned miscommunication about the tests and homework. Overall, students found Professor Drozd to be a “nice guy,” yet slightly “disorganized.”

The grade for the course is broken up into a midterm and final exam, three in-class quizzes, four to five graded homework assignments, and a global analysis project. The midterm exam is worth 20% of the grade and the final is worth 35%. The course is open to both Wharton freshmen and upperclassmen. MATH 104 is a prerequisite to this course.
